speaker: Clint
lines: Alright, to kinda just reset the scene a little bit, you are in this debriefing room in the security branch of the Berg. Also in this room, lounging in a very large, I dunno, throne-like looking chair, is a man who just identified himself as Richard, the king of the USA.

lines: I think he said, “I’m the fucking king of the USA.” [Clint [crosstalk] The fucking king.] And that cuss? Shook me to the core—

lines: That cuss was so unnecessary.

speaker: Richard
lines: Wait! Hold on, I think you’ll find this interesting. And this is gonna impact everything that comes after this. Okay so we’re gonna start off with a little history lesson, okay? By the way, I got crudités up here, I got sparkling water, there’s some shrimps if you guys want to munch on something while we— [crosstalk]

lines: I already have a mouthful of shrimp and I say

lines: Yes, I claimed the stromboli.

speaker: Richard
lines: Okay so, go back in history a little bit. King George the Third, King of England, did ya know his reign as king was longer than any other monarch before or since in England, 60 years and he was a fighter! He fought lots of wars, he fought in Europe, in Africa and Asia — well, he dispatched armies — but like any good fighter he knew when he was beaten, and in the fall of 1781 he got— he figured it out. He knew he was not going to be able to win [Remy Hell yeah]  against the American colony.

speaker: Remy
lines: America baby, we did it!

speaker: Richard
lines: Well it was too expensive! I mean, financially and his reputation, y’know— for five years he couldn’t beat a bunch of scrowdy row farmers in a war? Y’know, other colonies were talkin’ about it, the other crown heads of Europe were talkin’ about it, so Georgie Three was y’know, lookin’ bad to France and Spain and all his country club buddies, all the hoi polloi. So King George the Third decided he’d make a last-ditch hail Mary play to hold onto his rep. He realised he was probably gonna take a check in the loss column, but maybe he could put an asterisk next to it. August 12th, 1781, he signed a royal decree naming a regent over the Americas, basically naming a king to rule. But he did this in secrecy, and in secrecy, he had that decree immediately dispatched to America on his fastest ship. But it doesn’t matter how fast your ship is, the Atlantic Ocean? Not a good collaborator. So it didn’t show up until October 26th, that was one week after General Cornwallis surrendered to George Washington in Yorktown! Which basically made the American colonies a free state— but not… not really. Not legally.

speaker: Remy
lines: Should I be taking notes on all this?

speaker: Richard
lines: Oh no no no no no, no, bud, just let it work on you, let the story wash over ya, [Remy Okay.] ‘kay? Now, what people forget, there was almost a year of negotiations with England! Negotiating the peace! And those negotiations were headed up by the very man who was in fact, the new king of this country. And that was Ben Franklin. Ben Franklin was named the king of the colonies. And it makes sense, for most of his life, Ben really considered himself to be an Englishman. As a matter of fact for like, 10 years he was in England and before the war started he argued for colonial independence, so he was loved in all of Europe.

speaker: Travis
lines: Uh, side note, Clinton. This is Travis speaking, not Nadiya. How much of this is real to actual historical fact, and how much is Dad’s game bullshit.

lines: Alright and so, when the document finally got to Ben, he was torn, didn’t know what to do. Uh… but he really thought that this young country would have a better chance of survival as a democracy so he never told his wife. And he never told his son William. Who was a bastard by the way, don’t know if you knew that or not.

And down through the ages, it passed from grandparent, to grandchild. And that was the legacy of the King of the USA. With a bloodline leading all the way to—

And so, he has arran— he arranged things, and all through history, that’s what my family has been doing. Do you know that Ben was the first US Postmaster? [Remy Yes] Postmaster General of the United States. [Remy [crosstalk] I did know that] The first one.

speaker: Remy
lines: The White House, I guess?

speaker: Mary
lines: And what’re you gonna do?

speaker: Remy
lines: Hand over the king of America? I dunno I’m just thinkin’ out loud.

speaker: Nadiya
lines: You know the White House isn’t a prison, right Remy? Like we could go to like, Joliet, or, I don’t know.

speaker: Remy
lines: Yeah but you can’t just like take a guy to jail and be like “Here I got- got a new one for ya.”

speaker: Nadiya
lines: That’s true.

speaker: Mary
lines: Wh-what exactly, uh, crime, do you want him to be charged with?

speaker: Nadiya
lines: Sedition. Treason.

speaker: Remy
lines: Treason’s a good one, I mean he did sort of broadcast his treason to all of America so I think it’d be pretty easy to make a case.

speaker: Mary
lines: Maybe. Maybe… he wasn’t entirely wrong.

speaker: Nadiya
lines: Well okay.

speaker: Remy
lines: Alright, but—

speaker: Mary
lines: You tell me where to take him and we’ll take him there.

speaker: Remy
lines: I like the idea of the White House, I don’t know about you all, but I think it could be fun.

speaker: Nadiya
lines: I dunno, maybe the Pentagon?

speaker: Kardala
lines: Why does the color of the house figure into our decision?

speaker: Remy
lines: Oh, great.

speaker: Kardala
lines: That was a joke.

speaker: Remy
lines: Oh it was— hey!

speaker: Nadiya
lines: Oh!

speaker: Remy
lines: That one was actually a joke!

speaker: Kardala
lines: Thank you. Thank you.

speaker: [End music (The Adventure Zone
lines: Commitment Theme (Climax) by Griffin McElroy) fades in]

speaker: Clint
lines: And the skimmer goes zippin’ along the Gulf Coast, headed towards Washington D.C. Mary says,

speaker: Mary
lines: Oh wait, okay! There’s something else.

speaker: Clint
lines: She squinches her eyes, and a little panel opens, and out come a bunch of strombolis.

speaker: Kardala
lines: Yes.

speaker: Griffin
lines: [laughing] What a fuckin’ Archie Comics ending to this.

speaker: Justin
lines: I love it.

speaker: Griffin
lines: And Jughead gets his burgers.

speaker: Griffin
lines: So how close was that to what you were envisioning for the episode?

speaker: Clint
lines: Uh.

speaker: Justin
lines: Yeah I think a little bit of wrap-up would make sense.

speaker: Travis
lines: Okay.

speaker: Clint
lines: That was fairly close, I knew I wanted to have a confrontation. I actually was gonna involve a couple more operatives but then I realized that would have been too confusing and too big. And I really, I wanted, I want there to be a conclusion. I had no idea how it was gonna end. [Griffin Yeah.] I wanted there to be a conclusion, but I wanted it to still be open-ended if we still wanted to, y’know revisit these characters in the future, so… that really went— I’m very pleased with how it came out!

speaker: Griffin
lines: Alright!

speaker: Travis
lines: Well good.

speaker: Justin
lines: Good for the day.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Uh, as long as we’re debriefing, cause the point of this is to learn, learn stuff. I like the Fate system, I don’t think it’s gonna be a good fit for [Travis Yeah] the show. Just because kinda— the- the- the way that combat is almost like a negotiation? Or, uh, you’re constantly trying to like, calculate things with Aspects which I should say right now we were not especially good stewards of those, [Travis Yeah] we did play a little bit Calvinball to suit our needs—

speaker: Travis
lines: It’s great for gameplay, it’s not so great for like, rapid narrative storytelling? [Griffin Yeah, sure.] Especially when it comes to like, if you attack with this, which one do you defend with, that kind of stuff?

speaker: Clint
lines: Well I think it’s good, I think it’s good for storytelling, I really do think it’s good for narrative.

speaker: Justin
lines: Um.

speaker: Griffin
lines: It’s just not necessarily what we’re, what we’re doing but I had fun! I had fun with it! I think—

speaker: Justin
lines: Oh I loved Fate. It’s great.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Um. Um yeah. I think— I think we keep trying some. I mean obviously whatever we do next is gonna be a different system we’re still figuring it out, but yeah, that’d be great—

speaker: Travis
lines: Then we’ll be back with a different story.

speaker: Griffin
lines: Yeah great work Dad, that was cool.

speaker: Justin
lines: I liked all your great voices.

speaker: Griffin
lines: You worked very hard on voices.

speaker: Clint
lines: I worked very hard on voices.

speaker: Clint
lines: Apparently what was limiting me was just doing one!

speaker: Justin
lines: Just doing one— [crosstalk]

speaker: Clint
lines: [crosstalk] Yeah, I needed to do 24!

speaker: Justin
lines: [crosstalk] You’re too, you’re too multifaceted.

speaker: Clint
lines: Yeah I was just too big—

speaker: Justin
lines: Like a diamond with one facet.

speaker: Clint
lines: I was too good for the room.

speaker: Justin
lines: I guess.

speaker: Griffin
lines: So… I guess that’s it?

speaker: Clint
lines: We might have one after-credits sequence.

speaker: Travis
lines: Oh shit yeah!

speaker: Clint
lines: It’s a hospital room, and Richard is hanging onto life. He is surrounded by monitors and wires and uh, Martine is by his side, Sylvane is standing over to the side. The doctor walks in, checks the monitors, looks at her clipboard, looks at Martine, and says, um

speaker: Doctor
lines: He has a very long road ahead of him but I believe he’s going to survive. As a matter of fact, I would be willing to bet he’s going to… thrive.

speaker: Clint
lines: And she reaches up and flips over her medical ID tag, and it has a 24 question mark logo on it.

speaker: [Next episode
lines: Amnesty Setup]
